Introduction

The peripartum period (during pregnancy to 4-6 weeks postpartum) is associated with an increased risk for mood and psychotic symptoms due to hormonal shifts, sleep deprivation, and the stresses of being a parent.  Postpartum blues, major depressive disorder (MDD) with peripartum onset, and postpartum psychosis vary in clinical presentation, severity, and management, but they share some overlapping features.

Postpartum blues

Epidemiology and risk factors



Postpartum blues (also known as "baby blues") is very common, affecting 40%-80% of women in the 2 weeks after childbirth.  Factors that may be associated with developing postpartum blues include a personal history of MDD or premenstrual mood disorders, stress related to childcare, and limited social support following childbirth.

Pathogenesis



In the days following childbirth, patients experience a rapid decrease in estrogen levels, which results in upregulation of monoamine oxidase-A (MAO-A).  Increased MAO-A activity causes depletion of the neurotransmitters dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin, which can result in the depressive symptoms seen in patients with postpartum blues.

Clinical presentation



  • Onset:  typically within the first few days after delivery, peaking around 4 or 5 days after delivery
  • Symptoms:  mild depressive symptoms that do not impair the patient's ability to care for self or baby, such as low mood/irritability, crying, mood lability, and difficulty concentrating or sleeping
  • Course:  transient; spontaneous resolution <2 weeks after childbirth

Diagnosis



Postpartum blues is a normal, nonpathological response to childbirth that does not result in functional impairment.  There are no diagnostic criteria.

Diagnostic work-up and evaluation



Screen for suicidal/homicidal thoughts (signs of peripartum depression/psychosis).  Laboratory evaluation is not indicated unless clinical findings suggest another condition (eg, hypothyroidism).

Management



Provide reassurance and education on symptoms and their expected duration.  Emphasize the importance of sleep and encourage support from friends and family.  In addition, maintain close follow-up to monitor for possible progression to postpartum depression.

Prognosis



Postpartum blues is a self-limited and transient condition that resolves within 2 weeks.  However, patients who experience postpartum blues have an increased risk for postpartum depression.

Major depressive disorder with peripartum onset

Epidemiology and risk factors



Postpartum depression is estimated to affect 10%-15% of postpartum women and is commonly defined as a major depressive episode occurring within the first 12 months after giving birth.  MDD with peripartum onset has specific timing criteria: symptoms must start during pregnancy or in the 4 weeks following delivery (more common).



Several factors increase the risk for developing MDD with peripartum onset, including:



  • Personal history:  of MDD (either peripartum or non-peripartum) (strongest risk factor)
  • Psychological factors:  unwanted/unintended pregnancy, history of anxiety or premenstrual mood disorders
  • Biological factors:  young age, postpartum blues, family psychiatric history, other medical conditions (eg, gestational diabetes, hypertension)
  • Environmental factors:  sleep deprivation, marital conflicts, intimate partner violence, financial stress, adverse neonatal outcome, inconsolable infant (eg, due to colic)

Pathogenesis



The pathogenesis of peripartum depression is unclear, although it is likely due to the interplay of genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors.  These include sensitivity to peripartum hormonal shifts (estrogen, progesterone, melatonin, oxytocin) and neurotransmitter signaling/activity abnormalities (dopamine, serotonin, norepinephrine).

Clinical presentation



  • Onset is most commonly during pregnancy and within the first month after delivery.
  • Symptoms are the same as those of MDD and include â‰¥2 weeks of â‰¥5 depressive symptoms (1 of which must be persistent sadness or anhedonia) (

    ):
    • Nonsomatic symptoms (eg, mood, feelings about pregnancy/baby, guilt, inability to enjoy life [anhedonia], suicidal ideation) can help differentiate postpartum depression from normal peripartum changes (eg, sleep and appetite/weight changes).
    • Increased anxiety/worry (usually related to the infant's health/safety) is common.
    • Severe cases may involve psychotic symptoms (eg, hallucinations, delusions).

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of MDD with peripartum onset, symptom onset must be during pregnancy or in the 4 weeks following delivery:



  • The patient experiences â‰¥5 of the following symptoms during the same 2-week period, representing a change from previous functioning, and at least 1 of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia):
    • Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day (eg, feels sad, appears tearful)
    • Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day
    • Significant weight loss/weight gain or decrease/increase in appetite nearly every day
    • Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day
    • Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (as observed by others, not merely subjective feelings of restlessness or being slowed down)
    • Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day
    • Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt (which may be delusional) nearly every day
    • Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day
    • Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation, or a suicide attempt
  • The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.  And the episode is not attributable to another medical or psychiatric condition.

Evaluation and diagnostic work-up



  • Assess the patient for symptoms with a screening tool based on the patient's report of nonsomatic symptoms of depression.
  • Evaluate psychiatric history (eg, prior depressive or manic episodes, treatment).
  • Screen for comorbidities (eg, generalized anxiety disorder, eating disorder).
  • Order thyroid function tests (for postpartum thyroiditis) and complete blood count (for anemia).

Management



  • Mild to moderate depression (5-6 depressive symptoms; no suicidal ideation):
    • First-line treatment is psychotherapy with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT).
    • A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) (eg, sertraline) may be prescribed if psychotherapy is declined/unavailable.
  • Severe depression (>6 symptoms and/or suicidal or homicidal ideation):
    • Hospitalization is required if there is an imminent risk for harm to mother or baby.
    • Neuroactive steroids mimic allopregnanolone (a progesterone precursor), levels of which fall after delivery; upregulate GABA A receptors; and inhibit inflammation:
      • First-line: zuranolone (oral); 2-week course; benefits within 3 days
      • Second-line: brexanolone (intravenous); requires continuous monitoring for sedation during 60-hour infusion
    • If neuroactive steroids are unavailable/declined, then SSRI is recommended.
    • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is reserved for severe suicidality and dehydration/malnutrition.
    • CBT or IPT is recommended as adjuvant treatment.

Prognosis



Peripartum depression may resolve with or without treatment (depressive episodes last a year in about half of cases) or may progress into a chronic depressive disorder.  Of patients who recover, about half have recurrence (either peripartum or non-peripartum).  Depression is associated with impaired maternal-infant bonding, reduced rate of breastfeeding, poor nutrition of mother and baby, and increased risk for abnormal child development and psychiatric disorders.

Prevention



Screen for depression during pregnancy and postpartum period.  Closely monitor pregnant women who have a history of MDD (high risk for postpartum recurrence) and offer prophylactic treatment (antidepressant or CBT) in the third trimester.

Postpartum psychosis

Epidemiology and risk factors



Postpartum psychosis is estimated to occur in 1-2 per 1,000 postpartum women.  About 30% of women with postpartum psychosis have a history of bipolar disorder, but the majority have no prior psychiatric history.



Several factors increase the risk for developing postpartum psychosis, including a personal history of bipolar disorder (strongest risk factor) or psychotic disorders.  Additional factors include a previous episode of postpartum psychosis, family history of bipolar disorder, primiparity, and sleep deprivation.

Pathogenesis



The pathogenesis of postpartum psychosis is likely multifactorial and may involve a combination of genetic (predisposition to psychotic symptoms), biological (sensitivity to hormonal shifts after delivery), and environmental (sleep deprivation) factors.

Clinical presentation



  • Onset is rapid and dramatic.  Symptoms usually develop within 2 weeks of delivery.
  • Initial symptoms may include severe insomnia, irritability, and restlessness.  Other symptoms include delirium-like states (confusion, fluctuating consciousness), delusions (usually involving the baby [eg, possessed by the devil]), hallucinations, disorganized behavior, and suicidal and homicidal ideation.  The patient may also have manic or depressive symptoms or obsessive thoughts about the baby.

Diagnosis



Postpartum psychosis is a nonspecific term used to describe psychotic symptoms developing within 4 weeks of delivery and is not a standalone diagnosis.  The diagnosis is determined by associated mood symptoms (if present), such as MDD with psychotic features and peripartum onset; bipolar disorder, manic episode with peripartum onset, or brief psychotic disorder with postpartum onset

Evaluation and diagnostic work-up



  • Assess for suicidal and homicidal ideation (increased risk for suicide and infanticide).
  • Carefully evaluate psychiatric history for prior depressive, manic, or psychotic symptoms.
  • Perform a toxicology screen to assess for substance-induced psychosis.
  • Order a laboratory work-up, including complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, liver function testing, thyroid function tests, and urinalysis, to assess for other medical causes (eg, infection, pituitary necrosis).
  • Brain imaging may be indicated depending on clinical findings (eg, neurologic signs).

Management



  • Immediate hospitalization is required for safety.
  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Lithium and second-generation antipsychotic (eg, olanzapine)
    • Benzodiazepine (eg, lorazepam) for agitation
    • If prominent depressive symptoms present, SSRI added to regimen
  • ECT may be considered in severe cases or if patient is unresponsive to pharmacotherapy.

Prognosis



The majority of patients experience symptom remission with pharmacotherapy.  However, about half of patients experience another episode, either postpartum or non-postpartum.  In addition, there is a strong likelihood of a future diagnosis of bipolar disorder.

Prevention



Frequent peripartum follow-up for patients with a high risk for postpartum psychosis (eg, those with bipolar disorder diagnosis or a prior psychotic episode).  Prophylactic treatment with an antipsychotic and/or a mood stabilizer should be considered toward the end of pregnancy or immediately postpartum for women with a history of postpartum psychosis.

Summary



Postpartum blues, major depressive disorder with peripartum onset, and postpartum psychosis share overlapping features but differ significantly in severity and management (
